content: The "Military Commissions Act of 2004" allows for the use of military commissions for offenses under the law of war or in furtherance of terrorism. The "Military Commissions Act of 2004" allows for the use of military commissions for offenses under the law of war or in furtherance of terrorism. A military commission covered by this act may be appointed by the President or a designated person. It can try non-US citizens for such offenses and consists of three to seven members, with seven members required for cases involving the death penalty. A military commission shall consist of seven members, with the option of two alternate members. Each member and alternate member must be a commissioned officer of the armed forces. The presiding officer, who must be a judge advocate, oversees the proceedings to ensure a fair trial. Trial and defense counsel are appointed for a military commission similar to a general court-martial. Members deliberate and vote on decisions during the commission. Members of a military commission deliberate and vote in closed conference by secret written ballot. A person cannot be found guilty or sentenced without the concurrence of two-thirds of the members present. The death sentence requires the agreement of all members. The commission can impose punishments allowed by the law of war, including death, imprisonment, fines, or restitution, based on the President's limitations. A sentence of death may be imposed only for spying or an offense causing death. The President must approve the execution of the death penalty. The accused in a military commission has the right to a fair trial and is presumed innocent until proven guilty. The burden of proof lies with the prosecution. The accused in a military commission has the right to a fair trial and is presumed innocent until proven guilty. The burden of proof is on the prosecution to prove each element of an offense beyond a reasonable doubt. The accused must be informed of the charges in a language he understands before trial. He has the right to a public trial, cannot be compelled to testify against himself, and no adverse inference will be drawn if he chooses not to testify. Evidence obtained through torture will not be admitted in trial by a military commission. The accused in a military commission has the right to assistance of counsel, to present evidence, cross-examine witnesses, obtain witnesses and evidence, and access all evidence known to trial counsel. The accused in a military commission has the right to be present at all stages of the proceedings, not be tried again for the same offense, and have a right to review the finding and sentence. After trial, a verbatim transcript and record of trial will be authenticated, followed by an administrative review and necessary supplemental proceedings. The Secretary of Defense reviews the record of trial and can take various actions on the case, including approving, disapproving, or changing the sentence or finding of guilty. The Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces reviews military commission records in cases involving death or confinement over five years, or as prescribed by the President. The Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces can only act on findings and sentences after review by the convening authority and Secretary of Defense. It focuses on matters of law and follows regulations under Article 67. The Supreme Court can review its actions. The Secretary of Defense must submit all orders, rules, and regulations to Congress, with a 30-day waiting period before they take effect. The Secretary of Defense must submit an annual report to Congress on the use of military commissions, including case summaries, dispositions, activities, rules, regulations, and expenditures. Additionally, a new item is added to the table of sections in the subchapter. Art. 135a. Military commissions for offenses against the law of war or in furtherance of terrorism.
